pageData.text: Students will collect water samples from local waterways and test the samples for biological factors that governments and scientists use to monitor the health of natural waterways.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Bucket/container for waste disposal in field (optional)

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 40 minutes 
 Activity 1: Temperature Measurement - 5 minutes 
 Activity 2: Sample Collection - 5 minutes 
 Activity 3: Dissolved Oxygen and Biological 
 Oxygen Demand Test - 20 minutes + 5 days 
 Activity 4: Turbidity Test - 10 minutes 
 Activity 5: Coliform Bacteria Test - 10 minutes + 48 hours
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 40 minutes 
 Activity 1: Temperature Measurement - 5 minutes 
 Activity 2: Sample Collection - 5 minutes 
 Activity 3: Dissolved Oxygen and Biological 
 Oxygen Demand Test - 20 minutes + 5 days 
 Activity 4: Turbidity Test - 10 minutes 
 Activity 5: Coliform Bacteria Test - 10 minutes + 48 hours

pageData.text: This lab requires the collection of water samples at two separate sites. Travel time is in addition to times listed below. Times listed below are also “per sample” times.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Quality of Surface Waters: Biological

text: Practice proper water sample collection techniques.
Conduct biological analyses of field water samples.
Assess the health of local aquatic environments.
Compare water test results to environmental standards.

pageData.text: Understanding what is in our water has important implications for our health. While most areas regularly monitor the quality of their drinking water to make sure that it is not contaminated, more recently we have been learning from our wastewater as well. This wastewater, which flows into sewers, often contains urine, feces and other human waste products which, in turn, contain many indicators about our health. Wastewater has proved an especially important tool in fighting COVID-19. Scientists were able to sample wastewater to detect whether the virus was spreading in that area. They were also able to localize certain strains to specific areas and detect new strains almost as soon as they had mutated. This was especially important because, since COVID-19 and other viruses can have a long incubation period, the levels in wastewater typically rise before people start showing symptoms and needing hospitalization. This allowed hospitals to better prepare for coming surges, vaccine developers to track emerging strains, and public health officials to target resources to areas experiencing higher viral loads. With wastewater monitoring becoming more common and easier to do, it has become one of the main ways to detect outbreaks of not only COVID, but also Poliovirus and influenza, and may help us to prevent another disease from becoming a pandemic.

pageData.desc: A sewer manhole cover as seen from above.
pageData.altText: A sewer manhole cover as seen from above.

pageData.text: Water is one of the most common and precious compounds on Earth. Water covers approximately 71% of Earth’s surface, but only 2.5% of this is freshwater—and only a small fraction of that 2.5% is accessible for use and consumption. We depend on a clean water supply for drinking, cleaning, sanitation, recreation, and manufacturing. Public health officials and biologists have developed tests that can be used to monitor the quality of natural waters and to locate sources (and potential sources) of water pollution. In this activity, you will collect samples from local waterways and test and evaluate water quality on the basis of several characteristics used by scientists to analyze natural waters.

pageData.subTitle: Nitrogen and Phosphorous
pageData.text: Water is an important agent for dissolving and transporting many <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> (essential compounds for life) through the environment. The growth of primary producers (and, by extension, all organisms throughout a food web) in any environment is limited by the availability of a particular resource. That resource can be physical, such as light or space, or it can be a nutrient.

In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. Most fertilizers contain nitrogen and phosphorus as water-soluble nitrates (NO<sub>3</sub><sub>–</sub>) and phosphates (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3–</sup>). Rain washes these watersoluble nitrates and phosphates from cultivated land into surface waters where they promote the rapid growth of plants and algae, which speeds up the rate of <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>. Eutrophication is a natural, usually gradual process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies. Human activities, however, can lead to cultural, or human induced, eutrophication, which can speed up this normally gradual process.

Fertilizer runoff from lawns and farms, inadequately treated municipal wastewater, and poorly maintained septic systems all contribute to cultural eutrophication. In agricultural areas with dense animal populations, animal waste adds nitrogen and phosphorus to surface waters as well. Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. When these organisms die, bacterial-mediated decay depletes water oxygen levels, kills sensitive aquatic organisms, and contributes to sediment buildup. If nitrogen is the limiting nutrient, such as in most brackish or marine waters, nitrogen levels ≥ 0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural eutrophication. Phosphorous is usually the limiting nutrient in freshwaters. Phosphorus levels ≥ 0.1 ppm can accelerate natural eutrophication in freshwaters.

pageData.subTitle: Temperature
pageData.text: Temperature affects many chemical and biological processes. It modifies the solubility of oxygen in water, the rate of photosynthesis in aquatic plants, the metabolic rate of aquatic organisms, and the susceptibility of aquatic species to toxins and disease. Water temperature varies naturally with season and depth, but human activity also can affect temperature in significant ways. For example, heated water from surfaces—such as sunlit parking lots, roads, and sidewalks—and from industrial processes that use water as a coolant can flow into nearby creeks, streams, or rivers. This thermal pollution can destroy some types of aquatic life. Water loses heat very slowly, so thermally polluted water should be given significant dilution and time to cool before discharge into natural surface waters. Heated water also facilitates the rapid growth of some aquatic plants and algae, so thermal pollution can accelerate the rate of cultural eutrophication.

pageData.subTitle: Dissolved oxygen
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Dissolved oxygen (DO)</button>, or the amount of oxygen in water, is essential for biotic diversity in a body of water. Much of the DO in water comes from the atmosphere. Atmospheric oxygen dissolves via diffusion into the water at the surface. Wind and waves stir the water, which dilutes the DO concentration at the surface by mixing, and subsequently increases the amount of oxygen that can dissolve at the surface. Another important source of oxygen in water is photosynthesis performed by aquatic plants and algae. Some of these aquatic photosynthetic organisms are rooted or attached to the streambed, whereas others are planktonic (live in the water column). The amount of photosynthetically generated DO in the water typically peaks in the afternoon when the sun reaches zenith and the most light penetrates the water. <button class='glossary-text'>Turbidity</button>, or murkiness resulting from a large number of particles in the water, can lower DO levels by reducing photosynthetic rates due to limited light penetration.

Many factors influence the amount of DO water can hold. Water with lower temperatures can contain higher oxygen concentrations. Freshwater can hold more oxygen than saltwater. Another factor is altitude and atmospheric pressure; higher gas pressures result in higher gas concentrations dissolving into a liquid. Atmospheric pressure is greatest at sea level, so more oxygen dissolves into water at sea level than at higher elevations.

The amount of DO in a body of water can vary greatly due to all these factors. After a DO measurement is taken from a water sample, a percent saturation value can be calculated by comparing the amount of oxygen the water contains at that moment with the maximum amount of oxygen that it could contain at that temperature.

Respiring organisms, such as animals and bacteria, significantly reduce DO levels as well. Bacteria in animal waste are a major concern in waterways that receive runoff from fields and pastures where livestock are kept. When oxygen becomes depleted in the water, it is said to be anoxic. Anoxic conditions cause marine organisms to suffocate.

pageData.subTitle: Coliform Bacteria
pageData.text: Coliform bacteria populate the intestinal tracts of warm-blooded animals and disperse throughout the environment along with fecal material. When an animal defecates, large numbers of coliform bacteria (called fecal coliforms) are present in the feces. Coliforms also can be released to the environment from a decomposing body. The presence of large numbers of coliforms in a water sample is a good indication that animal or human waste has polluted the water. Most coliforms do not cause disease, except for a few Escherichia coli strains. However, many pathogenic bacteria and parasites are spread through feces (e.g., those causing typhoid fever, hepatitis, gastroenteritis, and dysentery), and the presence of coliforms indicates that harmful pathogens might be present as well.

Determining the presence of coliforms in drinking water and in swimming areas is a very important tool for protecting public health. This is accomplished by collecting a water sample and inoculating some of the sample on <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button>-rich medium that supports coliform growth. After several days, the culture will show bacterial growth (Figure 1).

pageData.desc: Figure 1: An agar plate with many small, circular bacterial growths.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: An agar plate with many small, circular bacterial growths.

pageData.text: This is the first step in determining the risk of animal or human waste contamination of a body of water. Additional tests can be performed to distinguish between total coliforms, which can have a number of sources, and fecal coliforms, which originate in animal and human intestines. There are potential risks associated with culturing pathogenic bacteria; therefore, this activity will only examine total coliforms.

pageData.subTitle: Total Suspended Solids
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Total suspended solids (TSS)</button> is a term used to describe and measure the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated. Dissolved materials and nutrients in natural water come from a variety of sources. Large concentrations of dissolved solids affect cellular nutrient transport, alter the taste of water, and interfere with industrial processes by fouling pipes and filters. Calcium and magnesium are two minerals commonly dissolved in water. A water-insoluble carbonate forms when aqueous calcium or magnesium hydrogen carbonate is heated. Industrial boilers reach high temperatures and generate solid deposits of magnesium carbonate and calcium carbonate, commonly called scale. These water-insoluble deposits reduce the efficiency of machines and are expensive to remove. TSS measurement requires the use of an analytical balance, which is not practical in a distance learning setting due to cost.

pageData.subTitle: Turbidity
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> test measures water clarity. Fine particles, such as eroded soil, and microscopic organisms, such as phytoplankton, contribute to water turbidity. Turbid waters clog fish gills, hinder disinfection processes, and carry entrapped pollutants downstream. Turbidity also blocks sunlight, which prevents photosynthesis below the surface and increases surface water temperature. Turbidity is measured in Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU). In this exercise, a modified turbidity tube will be used. A water sample is drained from the tube slowly, and the black-and-white pattern of a Secchi disk at the bottom of the tube becomes visible. At the point the pattern becomes visible, the sample volume is recorded and translated into NTU. If the pattern is visible when the tube is full, turbidity will be estimated using a saturation chart.

pageData.subTitle: Biochemical Oxygen Demand
pageData.text: Aerobic bacteria that decompose organic material require oxygen. In general, the more organic material there is in the water, the more oxygen demand will increase. When <button class='glossary-text'>biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)</button>, sometimes called biological oxygen demand, surpasses the amount of oxygen that can be added to the water, the water becomes anoxic. High <button class='glossary-text'>BOD</button> coupled with low <button class='glossary-text'>DO</button> input causes water-quality deterioration, which can result in the death of many fish and animals.

An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased BOD is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically generated DO levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

pageData.question: Which of the following is a natural process that can speed up the rate of eutrophication?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations.

pageData.question: Which of the following can cause an increase in biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eutrophication can cause an increase in BOD.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. For example, heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically-generated dissolved oxygen (DO) levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In terrestrial and freshwater environments, nitrogen or phosphorous are often limiting nutrients. An increase in nitrates and phosphates in a body of water often increases the growth rate of plants and algae. For example, heavy rain can cause a sudden influx of nutrients, which can lead to rapid and uncontrolled growth in aquatic algae and plant populations. These aquatic organisms subsequently die and are decomposed by aerobic bacteria, which consume oxygen during the process. Another cause of increased biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) is a consequence of fertilizer runoff. An influx of fertilizers and sudden growth of aquatic producers may produce a brief spike in photosynthetically-generated dissolved oxygen (DO) levels, but BOD rises as the aquatic producers begin to die.

pageData.subTitle: pH
pageData.text: Water contains hydrogen ions (H<sup>+</sup>) and hydroxyl ions (OH<sup>–</sup>). The concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions determines the pH (Figure 2). If the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions is higher than that of OH<sup>–</sup> ions, the pH is less than 7.0 and is considered acidic. Thus, the greater the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions, the lower the pH will be. If the concentration of H<sup>+</sup> ions is lower than that of OH<sup>–</sup> ions, the pH is greater than 7.0 and is considered alkaline (or basic). The pH scale is from 0 to 14 and is logarithmic; as the pH increases by one whole number, the H<sup>+</sup> ion concentration decreases 10 times. For example, a pH change from 5 to 6 indicates a tenfold decrease in H<sup>+</sup> concentration, and a pH change from 4 to 6 indicates a hundredfold decrease in H<sup>+</sup> concentration.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: The pH scale with common household items next their general pH.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: The pH scale with common household items next their general pH.

pageData.text: Water rarely exists at the neutral pH of 7. Saltwater typically is slightly basic, with a pH of 8 or higher. Freshwater usually has a pH of 6.5, but this varies greatly between bodies of water.

Organic materials can affect the pH of water. Fallen leaves often contain tannic acid, which stains the water brown and reduces pH. Some bacteria create acidic waste products that lower the pH of water. Acid rain has a widespread effect on natural waterways in the eastern United States as well. Oxides of nitrogen and sulfur are released into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels; they mix with atmospheric water and form nitric and sulfuric acids. These acids are mixed with rainwater and delivered to natural waterways and soils. Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid. Rain is considered to be acidic if the pH is lower than 5.6.

Many freshwater organisms have adapted to a specific pH range. For some organisms, the optimum pH range is quite narrow. A sudden or drastic pH change will kill some of these organisms or reduce survival and reproduction, which disrupts food webs and the aquatic community. Lower pH levels also can release heavy metals from the surrounding bedrock into the water. Once dissolved, these metals can interfere with the uptake of dissolved oxygen by aquatic organisms.

pageData.question: What is the pH of normal rainwater?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid.

pageData.question: Which of the following is LEAST likely to reduce the pH of water in nature?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Water will increase in pH, rather than decrease, with increased salinity.

Freshwater usually has a pH of 6.5, but this varies greatly between bodies of water. Normal rain has a pH of 5.6 due to dissolved carbon dioxide from the atmosphere forming carbonic acid. Rain is known as acidic if the pH is lower than 5.6. Organic materials can affect the pH of water. Fallen leaves often contain tannic acid, which stains the water brown and reduces the pH. Some bacteria create acidic waste products that lower the pH of water. Acids in atmospheric water that form when fossil fuels are burned mix with rainwater and are delivered to natural waterways and soils as acid rain.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-3 of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, submerge the thermometer in the test site water and record the water temperature. In activity 2, rinse the sampling container in the test site water and collect site water. If you are conducting activities 3-6 on site, continue to activity 3. If not, transport your sample home in a cooler, then continue to activity 3. In activity 3, completely fill the vials with water from your sample. For sample 2, wrap it in foil and incubate it for five days. For both samples, when ready, add the DO TesTabs, cap the vials and mix. When the TesTabs have completely dissolved, determine the DO using the color chart. Then, calculate the DO percent and BOD for each of the samples. Then proceed to activity 4.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 4 and 5 of this investigation. After completing activity 3, in activity 4, fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to sample disks to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. Keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Then record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value. In activity 5, add water to the coliform test vial and incubate it at room temperature for 48 hours. Then, observe the color change of the TesTab and any bubble formation.

pageData.text: Select each tab to continue

content.label: 2 LaMotte<sup>®</sup> Coliform TesTabs<sup>®</sup> (in the large glass vials wrapped in packing material)

text: Bucket/container for waste disposal in field (optional)

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Quality of Surface Waters: Biological investigation (item number 580833) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron anytime you are dealing with chemicals, including the TesTabs<sup>®</sup>. Natural water samples can contain harmful contaminates and organisms. Wear your gloves and safety goggles during sample collection as well.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Never conduct field work on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What percentage of Earth’s total water is freshwater?

A farmer’s son accidentally applies twice as much fertilizer to the crops during a growing season. Heavy rain washes some water-soluble nutrients from the fertilized land into nearby surface waters, which of the following consequences is likely a direct result of the fertilizer application?

options.text: A nearby river becomes turbid and sees many fish die.
A nearby river becomes devoid of algae.
The average temperature of a nearby river decreases dramatically.
A nearby river becomes home to an invasive species of fish.
Several local children develop colds after swimming in a nearby river.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT a common contributor to eutrophication?

options.text: fertilizer runoff from farms and lawns

assestmentData.question: What is the term that describes water with depleted oxygen levels?
Which of the following tests can definitively indicate the presence of harmful pathogens in a water body?

options.text: Inoculate nutrient media with water sample and observe any coliform growth.
Use a pH indicator to determine the pH of the water.
Observe a Secchi disk through a tube of water sample and determine its turbidity.
Place a thermometer in the water body to determine its temperature.
Collect patient data from those who became ill after exposure to the water body.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is used to describe the measure of material left behind after water sample has been filtered and evaporated?
Dissolved oxygen (DO) in water mostly comes from which of the following sources?
What ratio of bleach to water should you use to make a 10% bleach solution for this investigation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

typeBefore.text: Select your field sites for the following activities. This kit has enough test materials for two locations. You will perform Activities 1, 2, and 4 for your first sample in their entirety before collecting a second sample at a second site and performing the activities again. Activities 3 and 5 must be started before collecting your second sample, but the activities can run concurrently for both samples once started.

pageData.text: Ideal water sources include shallow creeks, rivers, springs, or ponds. Locate several possible test sites on a map in case one of the sites isn’t ideal for sampling once you visit it in person. Also, make sure these areas are accessible to you. Sites located in county or state parks are accessible, but for visiting privately owned sites, you will need to acquire permission from the landowners.

Activities 1 and 2 are performed at the field site. Activity 3 starts at the field site and is completed after 5 days of incubation. Activities 4 and 5 can be started at the field site or within 2–3 hours of sample collection. It is common practice to use a cooler to transport samples, because they need to be kept cool and dark to prevent post-sampling photosynthesis from skewing test results.

Select an area to test based on the way the watershed flows. Choosing sites above and below the convergence of two waterways helps pinpoint the source of any pollution found in the samples. Prepare a map that marks the chosen sites. Each site can be identified with latitude and longitude using a GPS or GPS-enabled phone. If using the Google Maps app on an iOS smartphone, drop a pin at your desired location and scroll up from the menu bar at the bottom to see the coordinates. If using an Android smartphone, simply look in the search box at the top.

For accurate measurement of dissolved oxygen (biological water quality), determine the approximate altitude of the sample location. There are several websites that can help you identify the altitude of a pinned location (e.g., https://www.freemaptools.com/elevation-finder.htm and https://www.daftlogic.com/sandbox-google-maps-find-altitude.htm). There are also free apps for smartphones, such as “My Altitude” for iOS and “Get Altitude” for Android. You can also determine your altitude once you arrive at your destination if you are an iOS user. The elevation can be determined by using the “Compass” app on your smartphone. Make sure your location services are enabled for the “Compass” app. Then just open the app, and the elevation will be at the bottom of your screen (along with the coordinates for your current location as well).
Read through the activities.

Obtain all materials that you need before starting the field trip. Make sure you have the LaMotte® Dissolved Oxygen TesTabs®, a pipet, the water-resistant sample comparison chart, printed copies of Table 1, the DO percent saturation chart, and Data Table 1, a thermometer, the sterile water sample collection bottle and vials, aluminum foil, gloves, goggles, a lab apron, a stopwatch or timer, the permanent marker, and a cooler with ice if you will be transporting samples.

At the test site, collect each sample from a location that is representative of the waterway according to the activity instructions. Best results will be obtained if samples are collected from locations that are not close to stormwater drains and drainage ditches. For the most reliable results, water samples should be collected midstream. Water near the shore generally is not representative of an entire stream or river, because some runoff is highly concentrated and has not yet mixed with the main body of water.

In some situations (e.g., if the water is too deep), it may not be possible, feasible, or safe to obtain an ideal sample. If in doubt of the depth or safety of the water, DO NOT try to collect a sample from that location. Instead, collect a water sample from a location you are sure is safe.
In Activity 1, you will record the temperature of the water at your test site.
While wearing gloves and goggles, submerge the thermometer 4 inches below the surface of the water.
Keep the thermometer in the water for 2 minutes. Remove it from the water, and immediately record the water temperature at this site in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will collect water from your test site for Activities 3-5. You will either prepare the water for testing on site or transport it home for testing.
While wearing gloves and goggles, remove the lid from the 125 mL collection bottle.
Rinse the bottle two or three times with water from the sample site.
Replace the lid.
Plunge the collection container several inches below the surface of the water.
Remove the lid.
Turn the bottle into the current, if there is one, and allow the water to fill the bottle. Hold the collection bottle underwater for at least 30 seconds.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Replace the cap while the bottle is still submerged. There should be no air left in the bottle.
This sample will be used for Activities 4 and 5.

In Activity 3, you will test the sample water from Activity 2 for dissolved oxygen. You will test one sample immediately and another after incubating it for 5 days in a covered vial. You will use the difference between the dissolved oxygen in the two samples to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>biological oxygen demand (BOD)</button>.

pages.title:
A
 Dissolved Oxygen and Biological Oxygen Demand Test (12 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Dissolved Oxygen and Biological Oxygen Demand Test (12 steps)

pageData.text: This test should be performed at the field site. Wear goggles, gloves, and a lab apron when performing tests on the field-site water.
Submerge a small glass sample vial several inches below the water surface. Make sure that the water completely fills the vial. Remove it from the water.
Drop 2 LaMotte<sup>®</sup> <button class='glossary-text'>Dissolved Oxygen</button> TesTabs<sup>®</sup> into the vial. Water will overflow from the vial.
Place the cap on the vial, and tighten it without allowing any air bubbles into the vial.
Mix the sample by repeatedly turning the vial upside down and righting it until the tablets are dissolved. This will take approximately 4 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Incubate the sample for 5 more minutes. This will be “Sample 1.” While waiting for Sample 1 to incubate, move on to Step 7.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: While Sample 1 is incubating, repeat Steps 1 and 2 with a separate vial and a sample from the same water source. Wrap the vial in aluminum foil, and set it aside at room temperature for 5 days. This is “Sample 2.”
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After Sample 1 has incubated, compare the color of the sample to the dissolved oxygen color on the sample comparison chart. Take a photograph of your sample being held up to the chart. Record the result as ppm dissolved oxygen in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: The remainder of this activity can be completed at home.

Calculate dissolved oxygen percent saturation as follows:
  1. To obtain the corrected DO value, multiply the DO (ppm) value by the correction factor that corresponds to the altitude of the test site. Refer to Table 1, the “Altitude Correction Factor” table.

1. If you have not already, print out the DO percent saturation chart. Locate the corrected DO value on the “Oxygen (ppm)” axis, and mark the point.
  2. Mark the temperature of the sample (calculated in Activity 1) on the “Water temperature, °C” axis of the DO percent saturation chart.
  3. Using a straightedge, connect the two points. The intersection of the line with the “% Saturation” value is the corrected dissolved oxygen percent saturation level for the sample.
  4. Record the value in the “Dissolved Oxygen % Saturation” row in Data Table 1.
After 5 days, unwrap Sample 2 and repeat Steps 3–6.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Compare the color of the sample to the dissolved oxygen color of the sample comparison chart. Hold your sample next to the chart, and take a photograph. Record the result as ppm of dissolved oxygen in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Calculate the by determining the difference between the two samples. The BOD is reported in ppm. Record the BOD in Data Table 1.

In Activity 4, you will test the <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> of the sample water you collected in Activity 2 by looking through the water at a pattern disk and comparing its appearance to control disks.
While wearing gloves and goggles, fill the graduated cylinder from your equipment kit to the 100 mL mark with sample water from your collection bottle.

Remove the cylinder from its base, and place it over the black-and-white pattern of the “0 NTU” <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> part of the sample comparison chart. This pattern, along with the “8 NTU” and “18 NTU” turbidity part of the chart, are acting as Secchi disks in this lab.

Look straight down through the water sample, and observe the “0 NTU” pattern through the water column (see Figure 3 for reference). If you can see the pattern clearly, proceed to Step 3a. If you cannot see the pattern, proceed to Step 3b.
  1. Looking straight down through the water sample, compare the appearance of the pattern you see to the disk patterns of 0 NTU, 8 NTU, and 18 NTU on your chart. In Data Table 1, record a turbidity value (NTU) that most closely matches what you see through the column of water.
    • If the appearance of the pattern does not exactly match one of the 3 disk icons, evaluate between which 2 icons the appearance of the pattern is an intermediate and then approximate the turbidity as somewhere between the NTU values of those icons.
    • If the appearance of the pattern is lighter than the 18 NTU icon but still visible, approximate the turbidity as somewhere between 18 and 29 NTU.
  2. Pour off 5 mL of water. Look through the cylinder again. If you still cannot see the pattern, continue to pour off water in 5 mL increments until you can barely see the pattern. (It may appear fuzzy, but you will be able to make out the pattern.
    See Figure 4.)

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Photograph looking down into the graduated cylinder to see the fuzzy pattern of the Secchi disk
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Photograph looking down into the graduated cylinder to see the fuzzy pattern of the Secchi disk

pageData.text: 1. In Data Table 1, record the highest volume of water left in the graduated cylinder through which you can see the pattern.
1. Estimate the NTU by comparing the volume to the volume in Table 2. Record the NTU in Data Table 1.

In Activity 5, you will use sample water you collected in Activity 2 to determine the presence of coliform bacteria. You will add the sample to the coliform test vial, incubate it for 48 hours, and observe it for color changes and bubble formation to determine the presence of coliform bacteria.
While wearing gloves, goggles, and a lab apron, use the graduations marked on a plastic pipet to fill the graduated cylinder with 10 mL of sample water.
Open one of the large glass sample vials containing a LaMotte<sup>®</sup> Coliform TesTab<sup>®</sup>.
Pour the water from the graduated cylinder into the open vial.
Return the cap to the sample vial, and tighten it.

Incubate the vial, upright, with the tablet flat on the bottom for 48 hours. The incubation area should be room temperature (21–27 ºC), and the vial should not be in direct sunlight. Do not disturb or handle the vial during the 48-hour incubation. The tablet will slowly dissolve into a gel-like substance.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After 48 hours, examine the sample vial. If the gel remains at the bottom, the liquid above the gel is clear, and the indicator remains red or turns yellow with no gas bubbles present, the result is <20 total coliform colonies per 100 mL of water. If, on the other hand, there are many gas bubbles present, the gel rises to the surface, the liquid below the gel is cloudy, and the indicator is yellow, the result is positive. Record the result in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: This test for coliform only confirms the presence of high numbers of coliform bacteria. The safety of the water for drinking should be confirmed by a testing laboratory.
Take a photograph of the vial to show your results.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Be sure to collect a second sample from a different location and perform all five activities again for this new sample.

text:
1. TThe samples that were tested for coliform bacteria should be treated as potentially hazardous. Be sure to wear your gloves, goggles, and lab apron when disposing of them.
    1. Dispose of one vial at a time.
    2. Open one vial, and add approximately 1 mL of household bleach with a clean pipet.
    3. Immediately recap the vial.
    4. Repeat Steps 1b and 1c with the other vial.

pageData.text: Allow the vials to stand upright for 4 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: 1. Dispose of the vials in the trash without opening. DO NOT reuse the vials after coliform testing.

pageData.text: Dispose of other solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions. If tests were performed in the field, dump all solutions into a “waste container” to be emptied in a drain with the water running when you return home. Throw away all other materials from the materials kit in the household trash.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: 1. Rinse the equipment from the equipment kit with tap water, allow it to dry, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
1. Sanitize the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.content: Figure 1. Bacterial growth on an agar plate
pageData.altText: Figure 1: An agar plate with many small, circular bacterial growths.

pageData.content: Figure 2. The pH scale and household items by pH
pageData.altText: Figure 2: The pH scale with common household items next their general pH.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 1-3 of this investigation. Before beginning, locate several possible test sites and determine the approximate altitude of each. Then, obtain your field work materials and travel to your test site. In activity 1, submerge the thermometer in the test site water and record the water temperature. In activity 2, rinse the sampling container in the test site water and collect site water. If you are conducting activities 3-6 on site, continue to activity 3. If not, transport your sample home in a cooler, then continue to activity 3. In activity 3, completely fill the vials with water from your sample. For sample 2, wrap it in foil and incubate it for five days. For both samples, when ready, add the DO TesTabs, cap the vials and mix. When the TesTabs have completely dissolved, determine the DO using the color chart. Then, calculate the DO percent and BOD for each of the samples. Then proceed to activity 4.

A map describing the procedural workflow for activities 4 and 5 of this investigation. After completing activity 3, in activity 4, fill the graduated cylinder with 100 mL of water. Then, remove the cylinder from its base and place it over the 0 NTU pattern. Next, observe the pattern through the water. If the pattern is observable, compare the appearance of the 0 NTU pattern through the water to sample disks to estimate the turbidity value. If the pattern is not observable through 100 mL of water, pour off 5 mL of water and observe the 0 NTU pattern again. Keep doing this until the pattern is visible. Then record the volume left in the cylinder and estimate the turbidity value. In activity 5, add water to the coliform test vial and incubate it at room temperature for 48 hours. Then, observe the color change of the TesTab and any bubble formation.
Figure 4: Photograph looking down into the graduated cylinder to see the fuzzy pattern of the Secchi disk

data.title: Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)
data.content: The amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present over a specific time period

data.title: Dissolved oxygen (DO)
data.content: The amount of oxygen in water

data.title: Eutrophication
data.content: An increase in nutrients in a body of water leading to excessive growth of algal and plant species which often results in the die off of other species due to increased turbidity and lower dissolved oxygen

data.title: Total suspended solids (TSS)
data.content: A measure of the material left behind after a water sample has been filtered and evaporated

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Murkiness resulting from particles suspended in water
